content.raw:
Trusty (and other platforms) are part of our CI system, they just are not selected to be "the reference platforms" for the PR CI cycle but they run daily to catch this kind of problems. Don't worry about breaking Trusty or other of the CI platforms, we can fix them as soon as the build cop detect the problem. This kind of errors (which depend of the Linux distribution) are not really common.

Thanks for the quick fix.
content.html:
Trusty (and other platforms) are part of our CI system, they just are not selected to be "the reference platforms" for the PR CI cycle but they run daily to catch this kind of problems. Don't worry about breaking Trusty or other of the CI platforms, we can fix them as soon as the build cop detect the problem. This kind of errors (which depend of the Linux distribution) are not really common.

Thanks for the quick fix.

content.raw: On a related note, should Trusty be part of the CI any build?  I have more changes coming, and I don't want to be continually breaking it.
content.html: On a related note, should Trusty be part of the CI any build? I have more changes coming, and I don't want to be continually breaking it.

content.raw: Pull request here: #!/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/336/move-codecvt-include-into-windows-only/diff
content.html: Pull request here: #!/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/336/move-codecvt-include-into-windows-only/diff

content.raw:
So, unfortunately, on Windows (where codecvt is used), that doesn't work.  I get errors about how codecvt_utf8 is not a member of std.  So it looks like we do need codecvt.

That being said, this is only really needed for Windows.  So what I'll do instead is move the include inside the Windows-specific header section, which should solve this for now.
content.html:
So, unfortunately, on Windows (where codecvt is used), that doesn't work. I get errors about how codecvt_utf8 is not a member of std. So it looks like we do need codecvt.

That being said, this is only really needed for Windows. So what I'll do instead is move the include inside the Windows-specific header section, which should solve this for now.

content.raw: Oh, sorry about that :(.  Let me do a quick test and see if that fixes it.
content.html: Oh, sorry about that :(. Let me do a quick test and see if that fixes it.

* http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/locale/codecvt

I don't think anyone is to blame here, since our `ci-pr_any` jobs don't test trusty.
content.html:
this header file is causing compilation to fail on trusty. should it just be #include <locale>?

  • http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/locale/codecvt

I don't think anyone is to blame here, since our ci-pr_any jobs don't test trusty.

update.description:
This is a PR to remove more of boost from sdformat.  This PR is mostly concerned with replacing uses of boost::filesystem in the library.

There are 2 potential problems with this PR that I would like to discuss:

1. If you look closely at Filesystem.cc, most of the Windows code is lifted directly from boost/libs/filesystem, then adapted to fit the sdformat style (along with various other fixes).  I'm not sure how the licensing works in this case; how do we proceed here?
1. There are no tests for Filesystem.cc.  The main reason for this is that I am missing portable versions of some primitives I would need to have reliable tests (change directory, remove directory, etc).  Should I spend time porting those primitives from boost, even though we don't use them in the main code?
update.title: Remove boost 11

content.raw:
Thanks for the update, @_jrivero_ .  I've now updated the top of Filesystem.cc to include the full text of the Boost license.

Given that this was a comment-only change, I'm going to go ahead and assume the previous approvals still stand.  Thus, I'm going to merge this up.  Thanks everyone for the reviews!
content.html:
Thanks for the update, @jrivero . I've now updated the top of Filesystem.cc to include the full text of the Boost license.

Given that this was a comment-only change, I'm going to go ahead and assume the previous approvals still stand. Thus, I'm going to merge this up. Thanks everyone for the reviews!

update.description:
This is a PR to remove more of boost from sdformat.  This PR is mostly concerned with replacing uses of boost::filesystem in the library.

There are 2 potential problems with this PR that I would like to discuss:

1. If you look closely at Filesystem.cc, most of the Windows code is lifted directly from boost/libs/filesystem, then adapted to fit the sdformat style (along with various other fixes).  I'm not sure how the licensing works in this case; how do we proceed here?
1. There are no tests for Filesystem.cc.  The main reason for this is that I am missing portable versions of some primitives I would need to have reliable tests (change directory, remove directory, etc).  Should I spend time porting those primitives from boost, even though we don't use them in the main code?
update.title: Remove boost 11

content.raw:
Two things:

* I agree with Steve and reading the license we probably need to include a copy it somewhere in the code (it could be done by adding an independent license file or extending the headers to include it). I understand that what the boost headers does is supported by the fact of having a license file present in software.

* Debian has [its own system](https://www.debian.org/doc/packaging-manuals/copyright-format/1.0/#license-specification) to represent the different set of licenses used in a copyright metadata file which could include the full license text if needed. So it does not matter what we do here since the debian metadata can workaround with any of the implementations.
content.html:
Two things:

  • I agree with Steve and reading the license we probably need to include a copy it somewhere in the code (it could be done by adding an independent license file or extending the headers to include it). I understand that what the boost headers does is supported by the fact of having a license file present in software.

  • Debian has its own system to represent the different set of licenses used in a copyright metadata file which could include the full license text if needed. So it does not matter what we do here since the debian metadata can workaround with any of the implementations.

content.raw: @_jrivero_ Any thoughts on the license treatment here?  I'm ready to merge this once we think that the license is all set.
content.html: @jrivero Any thoughts on the license treatment here? I'm ready to merge this once we think that the license is all set.

content.raw: You are absolutely right, Carlos.  I was originally doing something a little more funky in int_to_string(), but I eventually just changed it back to a straight int-to-string conversion, so there is no reason we can't just use std::to_string for that.  I removed that code and made it use std::to_string now.  Thanks!
content.html: You are absolutely right, Carlos. I was originally doing something a little more funky in int_to_string(), but I eventually just changed it back to a straight int-to-string conversion, so there is no reason we can't just use std::to_string for that. I removed that code and made it use std::to_string now. Thanks!

content.raw:
Ha, my intuition was completely wrong!  But this still won't work.

On Linux, your suggestion of using std::ofstream works just fine for both files and directories.  However, on Windows, std::ofstream::open works OK for files, but not for directories.

It is actually doesn't change things appreciably here, since we still need all of the infrastructure to support is_directory().  Still, it was an interesting thing to try :).
content.html:
Ha, my intuition was completely wrong! But this still won't work.

On Linux, your suggestion of using std::ofstream works just fine for both files and directories. However, on Windows, std::ofstream::open works OK for files, but not for directories.

It is actually doesn't change things appreciably here, since we still need all of the infrastructure to support is_directory(). Still, it was an interesting thing to try :).

content.raw: I switched the license, but what I did was to copy what the license header looked like in boost's operation.cpp (where I got most of this code from).  It doesn't have the whole license, but a URL to it, so I'm guessing that is good enough.  Let me know if you think otherwise, and I can put the whole text in (it is not all that long anyway).

update.description:
This is a PR to remove more of boost from sdformat.  This PR is mostly concerned with replacing uses of boost::filesystem in the library.

There are 2 potential problems with this PR that I would like to discuss:

1. If you look closely at Filesystem.cc, most of the Windows code is lifted directly from boost/libs/filesystem, then adapted to fit the sdformat style (along with various other fixes).  I'm not sure how the licensing works in this case; how do we proceed here?
1. There are no tests for Filesystem.cc.  The main reason for this is that I am missing portable versions of some primitives I would need to have reliable tests (change directory, remove directory, etc).  Should I spend time porting those primitives from boost, even though we don't use them in the main code?
update.title: Remove boost 11

content.raw:
Good point.  A quick comparison:

* current_path() - Same, except that std:: version returns a "path" object instead of a std::string
* create_directory() - Same, except that std:: version takes a "path" object instead of a std::string
* exists() - Same, except that std:: version takes a "path" object instead of a std::string
* is_directory() - Same, except that std:: version takes a "path" object instead of a std::string
* append() - Not in std::filesystem.  That's mostly because I created that out of whole cloth, since I don't really like the use of the overloaded operator / for this (which is what both boost and std::filesystem do).

With the minor exception of append, it seems like it will be pretty trivial to convert from this code to C++17 std::filesystem, when the time comes.  However, since we have to support older compilers for a while, I'm going to assume this code will live for a few years.
content.html:
Good point. A quick comparison:

  • current_path() - Same, except that std:: version returns a "path" object instead of a std::string
  • create_directory() - Same, except that std:: version takes a "path" object instead of a std::string
  • exists() - Same, except that std:: version takes a "path" object instead of a std::string
  • is_directory() - Same, except that std:: version takes a "path" object instead of a std::string
  • append() - Not in std::filesystem. That's mostly because I created that out of whole cloth, since I don't really like the use of the overloaded operator / for this (which is what both boost and std::filesystem do).

With the minor exception of append, it seems like it will be pretty trivial to convert from this code to C++17 std::filesystem, when the time comes. However, since we have to support older compilers for a while, I'm going to assume this code will live for a few years.

content.raw:
Has anyone checked if this proposed API matches the c++17 API?

* http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/filesystem

I don't know if the new standard is different from boost.
content.html:
Has anyone checked if this proposed API matches the c++17 API?

  • http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/filesystem

I don't know if the new standard is different from boost.
